column4: try sudo  dpkg-reconfigure -phigh xserver-xorg in a terminal then reboot
I even tried that after reading xorg.conf comments.  Boot still fails.
This is not the first time this has happened to me...
try sudo  Xorg -configure it will not change anything but will give you a new xorg.conf file you can play with. it will tell you the name and  location of the file
